Min/max intrinsics are monotonic, they operate on a fixed-bitwidth values, so there is a certain threshold value, upon reaching which, their value can no longer change. <a href="#a22ba75b1ff0a8caeed06d66c5c8ba8b3">More...</a>
</MembersIndexItem>

## Description {#details}

This class represents min/max intrinsics.

### getSaturationPoint() {#a22ba75b1ff0a8caeed06d66c5c8ba8b3}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="APInt llvm::MinMaxIntrinsic::getSaturationPoint (unsigned numBits) const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Min/max intrinsics are monotonic, they operate on a fixed-bitwidth values, so there is a certain threshold value, upon reaching which, their value can no longer change.

Return said threshold.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/intrinsicinst-h/#l00831">831</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/intrinsicinst-h">IntrinsicInst.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

  labels = {["inline"]}>
Min/max intrinsics are monotonic, they operate on a fixed-bitwidth values, so there is a certain threshold value, upon reaching which, their value can no longer change.

Return said threshold.

Min/max intrinsics are monotonic, they operate on a fixed-bitwidth values, so there is a certain threshold value, upon reaching which, their value can no longer change.

Return said threshold.
